Kolumna Bojana Budje: Pošta
Poštarji prodajajo vse in še več, ne zmorejo pa spraviti časopisa do bralca.
01 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Bojan Budja
Poslušam in berem, da bodo slovenski poštarji stavkali. In to na martinovo, 11. novembra torej, ki letos pade na ponedeljek. Pravijo, da zavoljo prenizkih plač in slabih razmer za delo. Težko sodim o tem, vem le, da se s pošto in poštarji veliko dogaja. Krajevne pošte druga za drugo zapirajo svoja vrata, sobotnega raznosa pošiljk in časopisov domala ni več, tudi ne časnikov po podeželju, redčijo se celo obiski mestnih poštarjev med tednom. Le njihova simbolna rumena barva ostaja. V spomin na neke čase, ki jih ne bo več.Vsega nekaj dni nazaj smo imeli svetovni dan pošte. V spomin na dogodek pred 145 leti, ko je bila ustanovljena Svetovna poštna zveza, pod streho katere se gnete že 192 držav, med njimi 27 let tudi Slovenija. Četudi – resnici na ljubo in razgledanosti v oporo – sega prvo dokumentirano organizirano pošiljanje pošte še v obdobje neverjetnih 2400 let pred našim štetjem. Ko so egiptovski faraoni po svoji deželi pošiljali vsakovrstne odločbe. Tudi ob sobotah. Včasih je bila simbol pošte kuverta, pismo. Nakar so jo Angleži že sredi 18. stoletja povezali s korupcijo. Kajti pismo je moral plačati prejemnik in ne pošiljatelj, cena je bila odvisna od potovalne razdalje in števila listov v kuverti. Če si jo hotel komu zagosti, si v ovojnico pač zatlačil kar največ listov in pošiljko odposlal čim dlje od naslovnika. Kuverta in korupcija sta odtlej nerazdružni, danes kuverte med drugim odpirajo vrata, ki bi navadnim smrtnikom ostala zaprta. Do zdravnikov, sodnikov, tožilcev, uradnikov, do vseh tistih pač, ki nas sicer zviška odpravijo z dvojko. Pismo že dolgo ne pooseblja več pošte.Danes so neki drugi časi. Čudni, težko razumljivi. Ko poštarji prodajajo vse. Pri njih lahko kupite vrtno orodje, pralni stroj, televizijski sprejemnik, spalnico, hladilnik, erotične pripomočke, kompresorje, sveče, dežnike, rože, računalnike, hrano za mačke in kanarčke, ni da ni. Ne zmorejo pa spraviti časopisa do bralca. Ljudem jemljejo sogovornika, prijatelja. Kajti časnik je več kot bežni znanec, z njim tudi debatiraš. Vse življenje sem časnikar, ljubim časnike, v njih verjamem. Ker so demokratični. V njih prebereš tisto, kar želiš, če ne, obrneš list. Kje v medijih je še to? Mar na televiziji, kjer lahko v premoru za reklame skuhaš večerjo? Tudi če stavkajo, poštarskega štrajka mnogi ne bomo občutili.

Bojan Budje's column: Mail
The postmen sell everything and more, but they can't get the newspaper to the reader.
01 Nov 2019, 21:25 by Bojan Budja
I listen and read that Slovenian postmen will strike. And on Martin's Day, November 11th, which falls this Monday. They say that because of low salaries and poor working conditions. I have a hard time judging this, all I know is that there is a lot going on with mail and mailers. Local post offices are closing their doors one after the other, there are almost no Saturdays of dispatches and newspapers, not even newspapers in the countryside, even the visits of city postmen during the week are reduced. Only their symbolic yellow color remains. In memory of some times that will be gone. Just a few days back we had World Mail Day. To commemorate the event 145 years ago, when the World Postal Union was established, under whose roof 192 countries have been bent, including Slovenia for 27 years. Even though - in truth and affection - the first documented organized mailing goes back a whopping 2400 years. When the Egyptian pharaohs made all sorts of decisions throughout their land. Even on Saturdays. It used to be the symbol of an envelope mail, a letter. It was linked to corruption by the English people as early as the mid-18th century. Because the letter had to be paid by the recipient and not the sender, the price was dependent on the travel distance and the number of sheets in the envelope. If you wanted to give it to someone, you just packed as many sheets as you could and sent the shipment as far as possible from the addressee. Envelopes and corruption have since been inseparable; today envelopes, among other things, open doors that would keep ordinary mortals closed. To the doctors, the judges, the prosecutors, the officials, to all those dudes who otherwise lift us off with a double. The letter no longer embodies the mail. There are other times today. Weird, hard to understand. When mailmen sell everything. You can buy garden tools, a washing machine, a television set, a bedroom, a refrigerator, erotic aids, compressors, candles, umbrellas, flowers, computers, cat food and canaries. But they can't get the newspaper to the reader. People are being taken by an interviewee, a friend. Because the newspaper is more than a fleeting acquaintance, you also debate with it. I've been a journalist all my life, I love newspapers, I believe in them. Because they are democratic. In them you read what you want, if not, you turn the leaf. Where else is this in the media? Is it on TV where you can cook dinner in commercials? Even if they strike, many will not feel the postal strike.
